intro: Phacelia californica var. virgata, commonly known as the Sierra phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and clusters of blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. It has small, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. This variety is known for its ability to thrive in poor soils and its role in supporting local pollinator populations.
